fact: Otters are mammals in the weasel family, Mustelidae, which also includes badgers, wolverines, and ferrets.
There are 13 living species of otter found across the world.
Otters live on every continent except Australia and Antarctica.
Most otter species live in freshwater rivers and lakes, but the sea otter is fully marine.
Sea otters are the heaviest members of the weasel family, weighing up to 100 pounds.
The giant otter of South America is the longest otter species, reaching up to 6 feet from nose to tail.
The Asian small-clawed otter is the smallest otter species, weighing only about 6-12 pounds.
Otters have long, streamlined bodies that reduce drag in water, making them excellent swimmers.
Otters have short legs and webbed feet that work like flippers for efficient swimming.
An otter's tail is muscular and helps with propulsion and steering underwater.
Otters have five toes on each foot, and most species have sharp claws for catching slippery fish.
Asian small-clawed otters have reduced claws, giving them better dexterity to feel for prey under rocks.
Otters use their sensitive whiskers, called vibrissae, to detect prey movement in murky water.
Otter ears and nostrils can close tightly underwater to keep water out during dives.
Otters can see well both underwater and on land thanks to special adaptations in their eyes.
Otters are carnivores that primarily eat fish, but also enjoy crustaceans, frogs, and other aquatic animals.
River otters love to eat fish, amphibians, crayfish, and sometimes small mammals or birds.
Sea otters specialize in eating shellfish like clams, mussels, crabs, and sea urchins.
By eating sea urchins, sea otters help protect kelp forests from being overgrazed.
Sea otters are a keystone species, meaning their presence is essential for the health of kelp forest ecosystems.
Otters have a very high metabolism and need to eat frequently to maintain their body temperature.
Sea otters eat roughly 20 to 30 percent of their body weight every single day.
Otters groom their fur constantly to keep it clean and full of insulating air bubbles.
Otter fur has two layers: a dense underlayer and longer guard hairs on top.
Sea otters have the densest fur of any mammal on Earth.
Sea otter fur can have up to one million hairs per square inch!
Unlike seals and whales, sea otters have no blubber and rely entirely on their fur for warmth.
Otters trap tiny air bubbles in their fur, which helps insulate them in cold water.
Otters can spend several hours each day grooming to maintain their waterproof coat.
Sea otters float on their backs to eat, groom, and even sleep.
Sea otters have loose skin pouches under their forearms where they store food and favorite tools.
Sea otters are one of the very few mammals known to use tools.
Sea otters use rocks to crack open hard-shelled prey like clams and mussels.
A sea otter often keeps a favorite rock and uses it over and over again.
Sea otters place rocks on their chests while floating and use them as anvils to smash shellfish.
Groups of sea otters floating together are called rafts.
Rafting sea otters sometimes hold hands (paws) while sleeping to keep from drifting apart.
Sea otters wrap themselves in kelp strands to stay anchored while they rest.
Otters can hold their breath for several minutes when diving for food.
River otters can stay underwater for around six to eight minutes on a single breath.
Sea otter dives are usually shorter, typically lasting one to four minutes.
Otters use their nimble forepaws to handle food with impressive dexterity, almost like hands.
Otters are famous for being playful and often slide down muddy or snowy slopes just for fun.
Sliding behavior helps otters travel efficiently between water and land.
Otters are incredibly agile swimmers and can twist, roll, and turn quickly underwater.
While otters are clumsy on land compared to water, they can still run at decent speeds when needed.
Otters communicate with each other using chirps, whistles, growls, and screams.
Otters have scent glands that produce a strong-smelling musk used to mark territory.
Otter droppings are called spraint and have a distinctive fishy smell.
Otters use spraint to communicate territory boundaries and reproductive status to other otters.
Otter dens are called holts and are often located in riverbanks or among tree roots.
Otters may use burrows, hollow logs, rock crevices, or dense vegetation as their homes.
Many otter species are crepuscular, meaning they are most active at dawn and dusk.
Some otter species like giant otters are highly social, while others prefer to live alone.
Male and female sea otters often form separate rafts except during breeding season.
Female sea otters raise their pups alone without help from the father.
Otter pups are born with their eyes closed and are completely dependent on their mothers.
Sea otter pups are born with fluffy, buoyant fur that helps them float like corks.
Mother sea otters carry their pups on their bellies while floating on their backs.
Mother otters patiently teach their pups how to swim, dive, and hunt for food.
Some otter species experience delayed implantation, where embryo development pauses before pregnancy continues.
Otters have excellent hearing that helps them detect both prey underwater and predators on land.
Otter whiskers are so sensitive they can detect the movement of prey in complete darkness.
Healthy otter populations indicate clean water and thriving aquatic ecosystems.
Otters need clean water with abundant fish and invertebrates to survive and thrive.
Pollution, especially from oil spills, can devastate otter populations by ruining their insulating fur.
Habitat loss from development along rivers and coastlines threatens many otter species.
Otters were heavily hunted for their valuable fur in past centuries, nearly driving some species to extinction.
Sea otter populations crashed during the fur trade era, dropping from hundreds of thousands to only about 2,000.
Conservation laws and protected areas have helped many otter populations recover significantly.
Sea otters are now protected under the Marine Mammal Protection Act in the United States.
River otters can travel over land for miles to find new water bodies.
Otters have extremely flexible spines that allow them to twist and turn with amazing agility.
When chasing fish, otters roll, spiral, and make sharp turns to catch their prey.
Sea otters use their large, flipper-like hind feet as rudders for steering.
River otters use their powerful, tapered tails like paddles to propel through water.
After swimming, otters shake and roll vigorously to squeeze water out of their fur.
Otters have a strong bite force that helps them crack shells and grip slippery fish.
Giant otters live in close family groups and hunt cooperatively, calling to each other constantly.
Giant otters are native to the rivers and wetlands of South America, especially the Amazon basin.
The North American river otter is found across much of Canada and the United States.
The European otter, also called the Eurasian otter, is widespread across Europe and parts of Asia.
The smooth-coated otter gets its name from its sleek, velvety fur that lies flat.
The African clawless otter has no claws on its front feet, giving it finger-like dexterity.
The spotted-necked otter has distinctive pale spots on its throat and chest.
The neotropical otter lives in rivers and coastal areas of Central and South America.
The marine otter, one of the rarest otter species, lives along the rocky Pacific coast of South America.
Sea otters live along the coasts of the North Pacific, from Alaska to California and across to Russia and Japan.
The Congo clawless otter is one of the least-studied and most mysterious otter species.
Just like humans, otters can be right-handed or left-handed when using tools!
Otters often groom each other, which strengthens social bonds and family relationships.
If an otter's fur gets dirty or oily, it loses its ability to insulate, which can be life-threatening.
Sea otters can sleep floating on the water, often with their paws covering their eyes.
Otters are naturally curious and love to investigate new objects in their environment.
Otter pups play constantly, which helps them develop hunting skills and social abilities.
Otters have strong forelimbs that help them dig burrows and manipulate prey.
Some otters can dive to depths of over 60 feet when hunting for food.
Sea otters spend nearly their entire lives in the ocean, rarely coming onto land.
Most other otter species split their time between water and land throughout the day.
By controlling populations of prey animals, otters help maintain balance in aquatic food webs.
Otters often return to the same favorite resting spots day after day.
Giant otter families can be very vocal, with up to 22 different types of calls identified.
Otter fossils show that the otter family has existed for at least 30 million years.
The hairy-nosed otter of Southeast Asia is critically endangered with very few left in the wild.
Sea otter mothers rarely leave their pups, even wrapping them in kelp to keep them safe while diving.
Baby sea otters cannot dive at first because their fluffy fur makes them too buoyant to sink.
Otters have special muscles that let them close their ears and nostrils completely underwater.
River otters can run as fast as 18 miles per hour on land for short distances.
Sea otters groom for about 2-3 hours every single day to keep their fur in perfect condition.
Otters have a third eyelid called a nictitating membrane that protects their eyes underwater.
